abstract.p: Letter from Zamir Akram, deputy chief of Pakistani Embassy in Washington, says Aug 28 editorial did not consider the circumstances that forced military to assume control in Pakistan after corruption, inefficiency and misgovernance turned democracy into a sham

block.p: Your Aug. 28 editorial ''Military Misrule in Pakistan'' does not consider the circumstances that forced the military to assume control, after corruption, inefficiency and misgovernance had turned democracy into a sham.

Your Aug. 28 editorial ''Military Misrule in Pakistan'' does not consider the circumstances that forced the military to assume control, after corruption, inefficiency and misgovernance had turned democracy into a sham.

Since October, the government has made visible headway in arresting the economic downturn and promoting law and order, good governance, grassroots democracy, a human rights culture and harmony between provinces. The devolution plan announced recently is designed to empower people at the grassroots level. Similarly, Gen. Pervez Musharraf has not ''put off'' the return of democracy until 2003. That is a time frame prescribed by the Supreme Court.

Further, Pakistan has repeatedly offered resumption of a dialogue to India, which New Delhi continues to reject. It is Indian intransigence that blocks a peace process, not lack of effort by Pakistan.
ZAMIR AKRAM Deputy Chief of Mission Embassy of Pakistan Washington, Aug. 28, 2000
